messageBody:
Hi Lee,

> Could you elaborate a little bit how you would approach this
>problem using JMock and CGLib?

You hit the target when you said it would be more difficult to do this;
I played around using virtualmock to mock out static classes that I
wanted to intercept. It turned out to be pretty tricky to set up, and
the tests themselves were hard to read and create. The general
consensus is that it's best to use these class-mocking methods in an
attempt to test while you are refactoring towards an easier to test
design. One way might be to create an interface of your own that is
either a thin wrapper of the target class, or else an interface that
exposes only the functionality that you use - though the difficulty of
this varies based on what the library actually does. If you take this
approach, you might be able to reduce the direct coupling with the third
party library, if (some might say when?) you're required to change
vendors.

Working with Legacy Code has a few sections on exactly this kind of
issue (separating concerns and dependencies on third party libraries,
not jMock with CGLIB).

>The good news is I am using Spring Framework in my application. I
>could use dependency injection to inject the third party classs into
>my class. If I don't have the interface for the third party, Spring
>would still inject the implementation class for me using CGLib instead
>of dynamic proxy, right?

I'm not sure on this one and will have to hand this off to folks with
some experience with jMock/CGLib with Spring.
